segments.text: Thank you all for joining us today for QANTA's first quarter 2025 earnings conference call.
My name is Carrie Liu. I'm the research analyst covering QANTA at Citi and will be moderating
today's call. Joining us on the call today are Mr. C.C. Leung, Vice Chairman and President,
Mr. Elton Young, CFO and spokesperson, as well as Carol and Ale from the IR team.
We will begin with the prepared remarks and financial overview from Carol,
followed by a Q&A session. Without further ado, I will now turn it over to Carol. Carol,
please go ahead. Thanks, Carrie. Good day and welcome to QANTA Computer first quarter 2025
earnings results conference call. The call is hosted by Citi Global Market Taiwan Securities.
The presentation material for today's call is available to the public on MOTS and on QANTA's
website at www.qantatw.com.
This is Carol. I'm joined today by QANTA's management, Mr. C.C. Leung, our Vice Chairman
and President, Mr. Elton Young, Chief Financial Officer and Senior Vice President in QANTA's IR team.
In a moment, we will start with the financial presentation. After that, the management will
host a Q&A to share our view about the business and industry outlook. During this call, we will
be making forward-looking statements, which are predictions, projections, and other statements
about future events. These statements are based upon our current expectations and assumptions
that are subject to lots of risks and uncertainties. As such, the actual results will differ materially
from our forecast. We undertake no obligation to update or revise any forward-looking statements.
So now, let's walk through the financials. We delivered another record-breaking quarter
in QANTA first quarter 2025. We sell gross profits, operating profits, and net profits,
reaching all-time highs.
This strong performance provides a solid foundation for the year ahead, which we anticipate will
be shaped by both significant growth opportunities and evolving challenges. Revenue for the quarter
was $486 billion, up 16.4% quarter-on-quarter and 87.6% year-over-year respectively. Thanks
to slightly better supply conditions for the latest AI servers, along with stronger lead
and expanded demand for general compute servers and notebooks, we saw strong sales momentum
throughout the quarter. Notebook shipments totaled 10.8 million units for the quarter,
representing a 2.7% decline from the previous quarter, but a 2.9% increase compared to the
same period last year. This outcome surpassed our expectations of a double-digit sequential
decline.
We attribute a strong shipments to the growth of the market. We also have a strong supply
of the market, with customers cooling forward demand at the end of the quarter due to the
uncertainty surrounding US tariffs.
The company's gross profit reached a record $38.5 billion, roaring 23.8% quarter-on-quarter
and 75.3% year-over-year. The gross margin for the quarter was 7.92%, representing 48
bps increase quarter-on-quarter and 55 bps decline year-over-year. The margin for the
quarter was $7.92% and reached a record $58.5 billion.
The margin improvement was largely driven by strong demand for general compute servers
and a lighter magnitude of margin dilution from high-end AI servers for slower RIP. Additionally,
a reduced sales contribution from notebooks also helped margins.
As servers outgrew other product categories, the sales contribution from servers reached
While the sales contribution from the market was lower than the average, the margin was
reduced by about 1.2%.
While the sales shares of notebooks was further diluted to below 25% this quarter, operating
profits hit an all-time high of $24.6 billion this quarter, representing a 62.3% increase
sequentially.
Year-over-year, profit more than doubled, up 110% from $11.7 billion a year ago, making
a strong $12.9 billion increase.
The operating profit was also higher than the average, with a higher margin increase
by about 1.2%.
The operating margin of this quarter was an all-time high of 5.07%, up 143 bps quarter-on-quarter
than 50 bps year-on-year.
Operating expenses was $13.9 billion for this quarter, going down from a record level of
$15.9 billion in both quarter-24, or 12.8% sequential decrease.

Stepping down the income statement, the net income after tax was a record $19.5 billion,
increased by 22.8% quarter-to-quarter and 61.6% year-over-year.
The net margin after tax was 4.01%, which grew 21 bps quarter-to-quarter and declined 65 bps year-over-year respectively.
The tax rate for the quarter was 22.1%.
And all of the above concluded an all-time high of earnings per share of $5.06 per quarter,
representing a sequential increase of 94% and a surge of $1.93.
Turning to the balance sheet,
Cash and short-term investments slightly increased to $215 billion, from $201 billion at the end of last quarter.
Account receivables reached an all-time high of $461 billion, from $371 billion in the previous quarter, reflecting the self-worth.
Inventory rose to a record $277 billion this quarter,
spending driven by cost-revenue.

down from $222 billion at the end of previous quarter,
due to the deduction of cash dividends of $50.2 billion on an actuarial basis.
Let's now discuss the ongoing plans for responding to U.S. debt.
The U.S. debt is expected to rise to $3.2 billion by the end of next quarter,
with a $2.2 billion return on the U.S. debt.
The U.S. debt is expected to rise to $3.2 billion by the end of next quarter,

As we highlighted in previous calls,
this contact business strategy is built on three key pillars,
advanced R&D, precise marketing, and manufacturing resilience.
Among these, manufacturing resilience has proven to be a competitive advantage
in today's volatile market environments.
Contact manufacturing resilience
is rooted in our extensive global manufacturing capabilities.
We translate R&D breakthroughs into commercial products

and respond quickly to market demands.
Reflecting the continuing competition, we are now able to expand our production capacity.
Our capacity for first quarter reached $4.7 billion, up from $2.6 billion in the same period
last year.
In line with this momentum, we revised our four-year capex budget to $20 billion.
We would like to provide some commentary here on several factors that will impact our business
performance in the second quarter and the remainder of 2020.
Driven by customers pulling in orders during a period of short-term carry pause and ongoing
manufacturing relocation, we expect that the strong notebook shipment momentum seen in
first quarter will carry into second quarter, then result in a high single-digit sequential
growth with upside potential.
However, this demand is somehow front-loaded.
We could see a more muted seasonal pattern in the second half of the year.
At this point, visibility beyond 90 days remains limited due to ongoing macro and industry
uncertainties.

Considering the evolving revenue mix driven by the accelerated shipment of new generation
AI server racks with higher ASP relative to lower ASP AI models, general compute servers,
notebook, photo, and other product categories. We anticipate some degree of margin dilution
moving forward. The new generation of AI servers went to mass
production in the late first quarter, while still in a slower ramp pace due to supply
constraints. On top of that, the demand for the lower ASP AI models remained strong and
contributed to the overall AI shipment.
As customers are urging for timely deployment of their AI infrastructure, we are seeing
strong demand and limited supply of AI. Given that revenues are tied to the timing of shipment
of respective projects, we could see variability in server revenue growth rates depending on
ASP mix and individual customer delivery schedules.
The AI server was a large contributor, driving the sales momentum in the first quarter, with
robust growth from both AI servers and general compute servers. AI server sales exceeded
60% of overall server sales, and their contribution will further increase in the second quarter.
The sales of AI servers grew more than double from a year ago, in good shape to realize
potential four-year growth for 2025.
Currency exchange fluctuations are another uncertain factor that would impact our quarter
performance. Over the years, we've been establishing a hedging mechanism to manage this rig as a
regular course of business, monitoring our net position exposed to exchange rate fluctuations
on a daily basis.
In general, most of our account receivables and compatibles are denominated from U.S. dollars.
The exchange rate risks tend to offset each other. Even during the recent turmoil in
the forex market, our hedging strategy has proven effective for our growing business,
and the risks remain manageable.
Overall, we believe the product mix is a key factor in the growth of our market.
The market has a greater impact on our margins than currency exchange fluctuations.
To close, we are pleased to present another remarkable quarter to our investors.
The first quarter result provided a great start to the year.
Though the outlook for the second half remains unclear, we are set for a better second quarter.
Thanks to our employees and management team for their hard work, and the support they
have shown for their dedication in achieving the unprecedented outcomes.
That enables Quanta to consistently make our way for a balance between delivering satisfactory

full_text: Thank you all for joining us today for QANTA's first quarter 2025 earnings conference call. My name is Carrie Liu. I'm the research analyst covering QANTA at Citi and will be moderating today's call. Joining us on the call today are Mr. C.C. Leung, Vice Chairman and President, Mr. Elton Young, CFO and spokesperson, as well as Carol and Ale from the IR team. We will begin with the prepared remarks and financial overview from Carol, followed by a Q&A session. Without further ado, I will now turn it over to Carol. Carol, please go ahead. Thanks, Carrie. Good day and welcome to QANTA Computer first quarter 2025 earnings results conference call. The call is hosted by Citi Global Market Taiwan Securities. The presentation material for today's call is available to the public on MOTS and on QANTA's website at www.qantatw.com. This is Carol. I'm joined today by QANTA's management, Mr. C.C. Leung, our Vice Chairman and President, Mr. Elton Young, Chief Financial Officer and Senior Vice President in QANTA's IR team. In a moment, we will start with the financial presentation. After that, the management will host a Q&A to share our view about the business and industry outlook. During this call, we will be making forward-looking statements, which are predictions, projections, and other statements about future events. These statements are based upon our current expectations and assumptions that are subject to lots of risks and uncertainties. As such, the actual results will differ materially from our forecast. We undertake no obligation to update or revise any forward-looking statements. So now, let's walk through the financials. We delivered another record-breaking quarter in QANTA first quarter 2025. We sell gross profits, operating profits, and net profits, reaching all-time highs. This strong performance provides a solid foundation for the year ahead, which we anticipate will be shaped by both significant growth opportunities and evolving challenges. Revenue for the quarter was $486 billion, up 16.4% quarter-on-quarter and 87.6% year-over-year respectively. Thanks to slightly better supply conditions for the latest AI servers, along with stronger lead and expanded demand for general compute servers and notebooks, we saw strong sales momentum throughout the quarter. Notebook shipments totaled 10.8 million units for the quarter, representing a 2.7% decline from the previous quarter, but a 2.9% increase compared to the same period last year. This outcome surpassed our expectations of a double-digit sequential decline. We attribute a strong shipments to the growth of the market. We also have a strong supply of the market, with customers cooling forward demand at the end of the quarter due to the uncertainty surrounding US tariffs. The company's gross profit reached a record $38.5 billion, roaring 23.8% quarter-on-quarter and 75.3% year-over-year. The gross margin for the quarter was 7.92%, representing 48 bps increase quarter-on-quarter and 55 bps decline year-over-year. The margin for the quarter was $7.92% and reached a record $58.5 billion. The margin improvement was largely driven by strong demand for general compute servers and a lighter magnitude of margin dilution from high-end AI servers for slower RIP. Additionally, a reduced sales contribution from notebooks also helped margins. As servers outgrew other product categories, the sales contribution from servers reached 65-70%. While the sales contribution from the market was lower than the average, the margin was reduced by about 1.2%. While the sales shares of notebooks was further diluted to below 25% this quarter, operating profits hit an all-time high of $24.6 billion this quarter, representing a 62.3% increase sequentially. Year-over-year, profit more than doubled, up 110% from $11.7 billion a year ago, making a strong $12.9 billion increase. The operating profit was also higher than the average, with a higher margin increase by about 1.2%. The operating margin of this quarter was an all-time high of 5.07%, up 143 bps quarter-on-quarter than 50 bps year-on-year. Operating expenses was $13.9 billion for this quarter, going down from a record level of $15.9 billion in both quarter-24, or 12.8% sequential decrease. On a year-over-year basis, OPEX increased by 35.4%, primarily due to the increase in Forex purchases andå¤± Phantom giving the first quarter when it was traded at Q1 2017. vaccin AS consciousness So if the pathway for OPEX 2018. Stepping down the income statement, the net income after tax was a record $19.5 billion, increased by 22.8% quarter-to-quarter and 61.6% year-over-year. The net margin after tax was 4.01%, which grew 21 bps quarter-to-quarter and declined 65 bps year-over-year respectively. The tax rate for the quarter was 22.1%. And all of the above concluded an all-time high of earnings per share of $5.06 per quarter, representing a sequential increase of 94% and a surge of $1.93. Turning to the balance sheet, Cash and short-term investments slightly increased to $215 billion, from $201 billion at the end of last quarter. Account receivables reached an all-time high of $461 billion, from $371 billion in the previous quarter, reflecting the self-worth. Inventory rose to a record $277 billion this quarter, spending driven by cost-revenue. The shareholder's equity, attributed to the parent company, was around $293 billion, down from $222 billion at the end of previous quarter, due to the deduction of cash dividends of $50.2 billion on an actuarial basis. Let's now discuss the ongoing plans for responding to U.S. debt. The U.S. debt is expected to rise to $3.2 billion by the end of next quarter, with a $2.2 billion return on the U.S. debt. The U.S. debt is expected to rise to $3.2 billion by the end of next quarter, with a $3.2 billion return on the U.S. debt. As we highlighted in previous calls, this contact business strategy is built on three key pillars, advanced R&D, precise marketing, and manufacturing resilience. Among these, manufacturing resilience has proven to be a competitive advantage in today's volatile market environments. Contact manufacturing resilience is rooted in our extensive global manufacturing capabilities. We translate R&D breakthroughs into commercial products quickly and cost effectively, enabling customers to capitalize on emerging market opportunities. Our flexible and scalable production infrastructure allows us to adapt to shipping customer demands and involving global trade dynamics. Our production network now spans nine major sites worldwide, one in Taiwan, two in China, Shanghai and Chongqing, two in Southeast Asia, Thailand and Vietnam, two in the US, Tennessee and California, one in Mexico, and one in Germany. The global presence allows us to offer agile, regionally optimized manufacturing solutions. Specifically, to address tariff-related challenges for AI production. Our magical facility has the flexibility to realize timely expansion, from focusing solely on manufacturing automotive-related products to scaling up AI server manufacturing capabilities as needed. This adds extra flexibility to support our final system assembly operations in the US. Alongside our existing AI production facilities in Taiwan and Thailand. If the policy conditions are clear and customers are ready to move quickly, we can complete mass production readiness within just a few months. This positions us to effectively support downstream production at our US sites and respond quickly to market demands. Reflecting the continuing competition, we are now able to expand our production capacity. Our capacity for first quarter reached $4.7 billion, up from $2.6 billion in the same period last year. In line with this momentum, we revised our four-year capex budget to $20 billion. We would like to provide some commentary here on several factors that will impact our business performance in the second quarter and the remainder of 2020. Driven by customers pulling in orders during a period of short-term carry pause and ongoing manufacturing relocation, we expect that the strong notebook shipment momentum seen in first quarter will carry into second quarter, then result in a high single-digit sequential growth with upside potential. However, this demand is somehow front-loaded. We could see a more muted seasonal pattern in the second half of the year. At this point, visibility beyond 90 days remains limited due to ongoing macro and industry uncertainties. We will provide more coverage on four-year guidance when additional clarity is available. For auto business, we are shifting our focus to the auto industry. We are also focusing on the auto industry. We are focusing on the auto industry. We are focusing on the auto industry. Like most modules and sensors. Instead, we are prioritizing resourcesful for the development of high-value and content rich products such as advanced data, card computers, and crop returns. To mitigate the current auto market uncertainty. resources relocation will help bolster our competitiveness for the upcoming recovery. Considering the evolving revenue mix driven by the accelerated shipment of new generation AI server racks with higher ASP relative to lower ASP AI models, general compute servers, notebook, photo, and other product categories. We anticipate some degree of margin dilution moving forward. The new generation of AI servers went to mass production in the late first quarter, while still in a slower ramp pace due to supply constraints. On top of that, the demand for the lower ASP AI models remained strong and contributed to the overall AI shipment. As customers are urging for timely deployment of their AI infrastructure, we are seeing strong demand and limited supply of AI. Given that revenues are tied to the timing of shipment of respective projects, we could see variability in server revenue growth rates depending on ASP mix and individual customer delivery schedules. The AI server was a large contributor, driving the sales momentum in the first quarter, with robust growth from both AI servers and general compute servers. AI server sales exceeded 60% of overall server sales, and their contribution will further increase in the second quarter. The sales of AI servers grew more than double from a year ago, in good shape to realize potential four-year growth for 2025. Currency exchange fluctuations are another uncertain factor that would impact our quarter performance. Over the years, we've been establishing a hedging mechanism to manage this rig as a regular course of business, monitoring our net position exposed to exchange rate fluctuations on a daily basis. In general, most of our account receivables and compatibles are denominated from U.S. dollars. The exchange rate risks tend to offset each other. Even during the recent turmoil in the forex market, our hedging strategy has proven effective for our growing business, and the risks remain manageable. Overall, we believe the product mix is a key factor in the growth of our market. The market has a greater impact on our margins than currency exchange fluctuations. To close, we are pleased to present another remarkable quarter to our investors. The first quarter result provided a great start to the year. Though the outlook for the second half remains unclear, we are set for a better second quarter. Thanks to our employees and management team for their hard work, and the support they have shown for their dedication in achieving the unprecedented outcomes. That enables Quanta to consistently make our way for a balance between delivering satisfactory shareholders' returns and investing in our long-term goals. Recently, Quanta's board of directors has resolved a record cash dividend payout of $50.2 billion, official year 2024 earnings distribution. The management also executed several rounds of capital investment in our manufacturing site in North America. The investment helped exercise the expansion of capacity and product production relocation specifically for A.I. server manufacturing. The expansion is providing us additional flexibility to respond to the US tariff policies. We are seeing CSP customers maintain heavy investment in A.I. in AI compute and data center infrastructure. The recent TAPEX guidance from top US hyperscalers confirmed that they are either maintaining or rising cap for AI spending in 2025, despite from a high base last year. As such, the accelerating AI shipment presents a major tailwind for the year. We keep working closely with our customers in an agile and nimble manner to effectively make the necessary adjustments to adapt changes. Over the decades, Qantas has had solid track records in facilitating prudent strategy, smart environment, and Excel operational execution to navigate through fluctuation environments. As we scale our global presence, we remain focused on driving improvement in productivity, efficiency, and utilization to help offset the growth in expenses and managing associated risks. Overall, we remain cautiously optimistic of our business for the rest of the year.
